text.content: WATCH THE BABY
Camila wants new sneakers.
She needs money.
She decides to babysit.
She takes care of little Mateo.
She feeds him lunch.
She reads him a story.
The story is funny.
Mateo laughs.
Camila likes him.
The baby's mom arrives.
Mateo gives her a hug.
Camila says goodbye.
She will watch him again.
REFRESHING MY DAY
It was a hot day in Barranquilla.
The sun burned the streets.
Carlos was sweating and thirsty.
He walked to the kitchen and opened the fridge.
There was no juice.
He grabbed three lemons and a pitcher.
He squeezed the lemons into water.
He opened the cabinets for sugar.
He poured two spoons and stirred.
He took a sip.
It was too sour.
He added more sugar.
Now it was perfect!
He drank it all.
The lemonade refreshed him.
UGLY DUCKLING BROTHER
Juan grew up in a poor neighborhood in Cali.
He had four hansome (good looking) brothers who were great at soccer.
Juan was thin and wore glasses.
His brothers called him "nerd" and laughed when he read books.
Their father (parent), a store clerk, preferred the athletic boys.
At school, Juan faced bullying for being different
While his brothers went on dates, Juan studied alone.
Years later, his brothers worked dead-end jobs.
Juan became a software engineer in Medellín.
Now he drives an amazing car and travels
His brothers still live with their parent.
The ugly duckling became the swan.
TREATING MY HAIR FOR SCHOOL DAY
María looked in the mirror before her school date.
Her hair was greasy and needed a wash.
She only had 20 minutes before class.
Desperate, she grabbed a rag with light color flowers to cover her hair.
She ran upstairs to check her pony tail But it looked out of place.
Her brother Carlos laughed from the doorway.
"You look ridiculous!" he said.
María felt envious of boys' just needed water to fix their hair.
She unwrapped the rag quickly Brushing her hair.
It wasn't perfect, but better than the flowery cover.
She ran to school, hoping no one would notice.
WILL MISS MY SCHOOLMATE
Camila lost her best friend Juanin a bike accident in front of their school.
A driver who was doing drugs hit him.
The driver survived almost unharmed.
Camila blamed his carelessness for Juan's death.
At court, the judge said this was the result of irresponsible behavior.
Camila decided to promote road safety in honor of Juan.
Her mother helped organize protests.
The driver went to jail, but Camila knew this wasn't enough.
She took responsability to prevent more tragedies.
Instead of grieving, she became productive visiting schools to teach safety.
She taught teens how to avoid dangerours situations.
Now camila works with the city to install traffic lights near schools.
Juan's memory lives on through her work.
SHOW ME THE MONEY (LUV) BABY!
Valentina was turning 18 in Comuna 13 neighborhood.
Originally, she dreamed of a huge party with a dirtbike parade, but money was tight.
Her hommie Santiago kept dropping hints about her surprise.
"You'll get no more boring birthdays," he winked.
On her birthday, everyone disregarded her.
No cards, no Happy Birthday, nothing.
At work, her expectations crashed when nobody mentioned her day
"Maybe they forgot," she thought feeling crashed.
That night, her friend Luisa called: "Come outside, time to party!"
Valentina opened her door to an awesome sight.
The whole block was decorated with Santiago driving his motorcycle
"Surprise!" they shouted.
Valentina was elated.
The party had local dancers and her favorite foods.
She felt greatful for her unique community.
This was better than any expensive (celebration).
